raw_text:
Kilroy names election seat target
 
 Ex-chat show host Robert Kilroy-Silk is to contest the Derbyshire seat of Erewash at the next general election.
 
 Labour's Elizabeth Blackman won the seat in 1997 and has a 6,932 majority. She says she will fight on her record "as a hard-working constituency MP". Mr Kilroy-Silk announced his plans a day after launching his new party, Veritas, the Latin for truth. The East Midlands MEP, who quit the UK Independence Party, wants his new group to "change the face" of UK politics. His choice of election constituency quashes speculation that he would stand against Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon in Ashfield, Nottinghamshire. UKIP won 31% of the vote in Erewash in last June's European elections - with Mr Kilroy-Silk among their candidates for the region. Until 1997, Erewash had been held by the Tories since 1970. Ms Blackman said she was proud of the government's achievements in the area. She declined to give her view of Mr Kilroy-Silk at this point.
 
 On Thursday, he told a London news conference that Veritas would avoid the old parties' "lies and spin". He said "our country" was being "stolen from us" by mass immigration and promised a "firm but fair" policy on immigration. Veritas says it hopes to contest most seats at the forthcoming general election but plans to announce detailed policies on crime, tax, pensions, health and defence over the next few weeks.
 
 UKIP leader Roger Knapman says he is glad to see the back of Mr Kilroy-Silk. Labour campaign spokesman Fraser Kemp said Veritas was joining "an already crowded field on the right of British politics". Mr Kilroy-Silk was joined in the new venture by one of UKIP's two London Assembly members, Damien Hockney, who is now Veritas' deputy leader.
 
 UKIP's chairman Petrina Holdsworth has said the group will just be a parody of the party the men have left. Mr Kilroy-Silk quit UKIP last week after months of tension as he vied unsuccessfully for the leadership of that party. He said he was ashamed to be a member of a UKIP whose leadership had "gone AWOL" after the great opportunity offered by its third place at last June's European elections. UKIP's leader, Roger Knapman, has said he is glad to see the back of Mr Kilroy-Silk. "He has remarkable ability to influence people but, sadly, after the [European] election it became clear that he was more interested in the Robert Kilroy-Silk Party than the UK Independence Party so it was nice knowing him, now 'goodbye'," he said. UKIP officials also argue Mr Kilroy-Silk has not been "straightforward" in attacking the party he once wanted to lead.
llama3.2:1b: Robert Kilroy-Silk will contest Erewash constituency at the next general election after announcing his new party Veritas.
Labour's Elizabeth Blackman is the current MP for the seat, which she won in 1997 with a 6,932 majority.
She plans to fight on her record and defend the government's achievements in the area.
Kilroy-Silk will contest most seats at the general election but has not announced specific policies yet.
llama3.2:3b: Robert Kilroy-Silk announces plans to contest Derbyshire's Erewash seat at the next general election, quitting UK Independence Party after months of tension over leadership.
gemma2:2b: Robert Kilroy-Silk will contest the Erewash seat in the next general election.
He formed a new party called Veritas, which aims to change politics.
Veritas plans to contest most seats, and it has policies on immigration, crime, tax, pensions, health, and defense.
UKIP leader Roger Knapman is glad to see Kilroy-Silk leave UKIP.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UKIP's new political group Veritas will contest most seats at the 2018 general election but is still a short way from making its name as an alternative British politician.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Robert Kilroy-Silk is running as a member of Veritas to contest the Derbyshire seat of Erewash in the next general election, aiming to change politics' face and address immigration issues.
This choice contradicts previous speculation about him opposing Labour's Geoff Hoon in Ashfield.
qwen2.5:3b: Ex-chat show host Robert Kilroy-Silk is contesting the Erewash seat for the next general election as a member of his new party, Veritas.
Labour's Elizabeth Blackman won the seat in 1997 with a majority of 6,932.
Kilroy-Silk previously quit the UK Independence Party (UKIP) and wants to "change the face" of UK politics.
UKIP won 31% of the vote in Erewash during last June's European elections, where Kilroy-Silk was one of their candidates.
Until 1997, Erewash had been held by the Tories since 1970.
Veritas plans to contest most seats at the upcoming general election and announce detailed policies on crime, tax, pensions, health, and defense over the next few weeks.
UKIP leader Roger Knapman expressed his gladness at Kilroy-Silk leaving their party, while Labour campaign spokesman Fraser Kemp noted that Veritas is joining "an already crowded field."
Petrina Holdsworth of UKIP suggested that Veritas will be a parody of the party they have left after its third place in June's European elections.

UKIP officials also argue Mr Kilroy-Silk has not been "straightforward" in attacking the party he once wanted to lead.
The election's outcome doesn't affect his standing as a member of the party.
smollm:1.7b: Kilroy-Silk is a Labour candidate for the Derbyshire seat at the next general election.
The Labour Party's Elizabeth Blackman won the seat in 1997 and has a majority of 6,932 votes.
The Labour Party's Elizabeth Blackman wants to fight on her record as a hard-working constituency MP.
The Labour Party's Elizabeth Blackman is not running for election against Mr Kilroy-Silk in Ashfield, Nottinghamshire.
UKIP won 31% of the vote in Erewash at last June's European elections - with the Labour candidate among their candidates for the region.
UKIP will announce detailed policies on crime, tax, pensions, health and defence over the next few weeks.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Robert Kilroy-Silk is running for Erewash election seat.
He announced plans of launching Veritas, a group focused on truth, to change UK politics.
He won the seat in 1997 with a 6,932 majority, and his record as a hardworking constituency MP.
He aims to fight against lies and spin from old parties.
He is running against someone else but hasn't faced speculation about his opposition.
He wants to focus on immigration issues like mass migration and voter strategy for the next election.
His previous term was from 1970, held by Tories since 1970.
He didn't face claims of back-to-back seats with UKIP members, and they are collaborating as a parody group.
He said Veritas will avoid old party lies and spin, focusing on immigration.
tinyllama:1.1b: The former chat show host Robert Kilroy-Silk is set to contest the Derbyshire seat of Erewash at the next general election, after announcing his new party, Veritas, on social media a day after launching his new party, Veritas, the Latin for truth.
Mr Kilroy-Silk's choice of election constituency follows speculation that he would stand against Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon in Ashfield, Nottinghamshire.
UKIP leader Roger Knapman said he is glad to see the back of Mr Kilroy-Silk and that Veritas aims to campaign on crime, tax, penalties, health, defection, over the next few weeks.

UKIP's chairman Petrină Holdsworth said the group would be "a parody" of the party UKIP had left, but UKIP leader Roger Knapman said that he was happy to see Kilroy-Silk join Veritas and hoped the group could contest most seats.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Elections are a crucial part of maintaining democracy and electoral systems can be quite complex, which is why it's important for everyone involved to know what's happening.
In this case, Robert Kilroy-Silk, who was known as the "Kilroy-Silk Seat Target" in his past role, has announced that he will be contesting the next general election seat in Derbyshire.
This means that he will be trying to unseat Elizabeth Blackman from her position as a local constituency MP for Erewash.
The election is set for May 5th and it's unclear who will stand against Ms Blackman.
However, a new party has been launched called Veritas, which seems to be inspired by UKIP.
Their leader, Robert Kilroy-Silk, announced that they will not align themselves with any of the existing parties in the election.
UKIP won the seat in the last general election in 1997, and their candidate at that time was a woman named Elizabeth Blackman.
She had a majority of around 6,000 votes at that time.
Since then, however, UKIP's popularity has plummeted.
It is uncertain whether Mr Kilroy-Silk will stand against Ms Blackman or whether they will work with her.
The choice of the election seat depends on which group wins the majority of the votes.
As for Robert Kilroy-Silk, he quit the UKIP in November last year after some disagreements.

He claims that the party had become "AOL" (the acronym for "Any Other Party") and was more interested in their third-place performance at the European elections than the success of the UK Independence Party.
While we cannot predict who will win this election or which political group will control the seat, it is clear that there is a lot of political drama involved.
phi:2.7b: Ex-MP Robert Kilroy-Silk is launching a new political party called Veritas and will contest the Derbyshire seat of Erewash at the next general election.
He wants to change UK politics by promoting truth over lies and spin.
Veritas hopes to have policies on crime, tax, pensions, health and defence ready for announcement in the next few weeks.
Robert Kilroy-Silk left the UK Independence Party (UKIP) last week after a leadership dispute, but has joined forces with UKIP London Assembly member Damien Hockney.
The party will just be a parody of UKIP, says Petrina Holdsworth, chairman of UKIP.
UKIP's former leader, Roger Knapman, is glad to see Kilroy-Silk go and hopes Veritas will not take the place of his party.
orca-mini:3b: Kilroy names election seat target - Ex-chat show host Robert Kilroy-Silk is contesting the Derbyshire seat of Erewash at the next general election, after Labour's Elizabeth Blackman won the majority of 6,932 in 1997.
However, she has declined to give her view of Mr Kilroy-Silk at this point.
UKIP's Elizabeth Blackman, who held the seat, said Veritas would avoid "lies and spin" but hopes to announce detailed policies on crime, tax, pensions, health and defence over the next few weeks.
Roger Knapman, UKIP's chairman, says he is glad to see the back of Mr Kilroy-Silk after months of tension as he vied unsuccessfully for the leadership of that party.
Mr Kilroy-Silk was joined in Veritas by Damien Hockney, a London Assembly member, and Petrina Holdsworth, who said the group would just be a parody of UKIP.
hermes3:3b: Robert Kilroy-Silk to contest Erewash seat at next general election; Labour's Elizabeth Blackman holds with majority of 6,932.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ex-chat show host Robert Kilroy-Silk is running for the Derbyshire seat of Erewash in the next general election, as his new party Veritas aims to "change the face" of UK politics.
Kilroy-Silk left UKIP after months of tension and launched Veritas with promises of firm but fair immigration policies and detailed plans on crime, tax, pensions, health, and defense.
He joins UKIP's leader Roger Knapman in expressing gladness at Kilroy-Silk's departure.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Robert Kilroy-Silk, former chat show host and ex-UKIP member, will contest the Derbyshire seat of Erewash in the next general election under his newly launched party, Veritas.
Labour's Elizabeth Blackman, who has held the seat since 1997, vows to defend her record.
Kilroy-Silk, an East Midlands MEP, aims to "change the face" of UK politics and has ruled out standing against Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon.
Veritas plans to contest most seats and will soon announce policies on key issues, including immigration, which Kilroy-Silk claims is "stealing" the country.
His departure from UKIP followed leadership tensions, with UKIP leader Roger Knapman expressing relief at his exit.
UKIP officials accuse Kilroy-Silk of being self-serving and attacking the party he once sought to lead.
Veritas' deputy leader is Damien Hockney, a former UKIP London Assembly member.
Labour campaigners dismiss Veritas as another right-wing party, while UKIP figures mock it as a parody of their own party.
stablelm2:1.6b: Ex-chat show host Robert Kilroy- Silk is running for the Derbyshire seat of Erewash at the next general election, as Labour's Elizabeth Blackman holds a significant 6% majority.
Kilroy-Silk launched his new group Veritas (Latin for truth), aiming to change the face of UK politics and avoid "old parties' lies and spin."
Veritas promises a firm but fair policy on immigration and plans to contest most seats at the upcoming election.
UKIP won 20% of the vote in Erewash in June's European elections, with Kilroy-Silk among their candidates for the region.
He announced his support for Veritas, avoiding a potential stand against Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon in Ashfield, Nottinghamshire.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Robert Kilroy-Silk, a former UK Independence Party (UKIP) member and TV host, will run for the Derbyshire seat of Erewash in the upcoming general election as part of his new political party, Veritas.
The 6,932 majority held by Labour's Elizabeth Blackman, who has served since 1997, remains unchallenged.
Kilroy-Silk announced this decision on the same day he launched Veritas, aiming to transform UK politics with a commitment to transparency and an end to perceived "lies and spin."
He plans to address issues like immigration, crime, tax, pensions, healthcare, and defense.
UKIP's chairman, Petrina Holdsworth, claims Veritas will merely mimic the disbanded party.
UKIP leader Roger Knapman expressed relief at Kilroy-Silk's departure, stating he was more focused on his new venture than on UKIP.
Kilroy-Silk had been vying for the UKIP leadership but lost out and grew disillusioned with the party's management after its strong European election performance in June 2014.
His decision to join forces with fellow UKIP member Damien Hockney, now Veritas' deputy leader, underscores his growing distance from UKIP.
Labour sees Veritas as an additional right-wing contender, while a Labour campaign spokesman described it as joining "an already crowded field."
